description.narrative: This project specifically addresses the threats posed by the illegal and unsustainable wildlife trade to endangered species in Indonesia.

activity-description.narrative: Scaling-up of on-the-ground implementation of improved enforcement capacity and strategies including the Wildlife Crime Unit (WCU)
Systematic assessment and capacity building for wildlife trade ports
Systematic assessment and capacity building for wildlife trade ports
Systematic assessment and capacity building for wildlife trade ports

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
0.1: Extent to which legal or policy or institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems. (IRRF Output 2.5 indicator 2.5.1)
0.2: Number of direct project beneficiaries: - Number of government agency staff including enforcement officers who improved their knowledge and skills on IWT due to the project (m/f) - Number of local people in project demonstration areas benefiting from engagement in conservation activities, reduced HWC impacts and improved livelihoods (m/f)
0.3: Expert evaluation of IWT annual volume (number of animal specimens – body parts or live animals) in Indonesia based on the WCS IWT database
0.4: Number of individuals of IWT flagship species (Sumatran Tiger, Sumatran Rhinoceros, Sumatran Elephant, Black-crested macaque, Anoa and Babirusa) killed by poachers annually in the 2 project demonstration areas

comment.narrative:
1.) UU5/1990 need to be revised (the current law has not specifically addressed IWT issue; PP7/1999 has not been revised
2.) 4666 wild animals are seized from 34 protected species
Source: Lakip, Gakkum 2016
3.) 2015: Tiger (5 poached); Elephant (7 poached); Rhino (1 poached); Anoa (10 poached), Babirusa (12), Black-crested macaque (~200

1. The project continued the efforts to effective implementation of the national strategy for combating illegal wildlife trade (IWT). It has been completed but it is waiting for legalization to ensure effective adoption, planning and budgeting within MoEF and potentially to be referred by other law enforcement agencies. The strategy has been endorsed by the project board.
2. Two bilateral cooperation have been facilitated through repatriation programme of the illegally traded/smuggled Orangutans in Thailand and Malaysia. This was happened as the results of data sharing and join commitment to combat IWT in the region. The project facilitated development of the Android-based mobile application to identify protected wildlife species which will be used by Government officers in seaports and airports. The existing digital-based operation rooms are operational and delivering inputs in planning, budgeting and making more effective CIWT operations. The analysis from cyber patrol team is also useful to prioritize interventions in suspected areas.
3. The project facilitated the capacities of Bakauheuni seaport check point in Lampung province which is a critical hub for IWT from Sumatera to Java island. Similar efforts have been done in Bitung seaport. To keep the significant results on the law enforcement, the project supported relevant officers in developing participative CIWT plan. In addition, a training on basic investigation technique has been conducted for Boganinani national park in North Sulawesi.
4. Several evidences are available to confirm achievement of the knowledge management target. The project has shared the good practices in the Global Wildlife Programme Conference. Gender-related knowledge products has been produced such as training modules, syllabus, and campaign materials. The project successful in organizing series of gender leadership training which received acknowledgement from the Minister of Environment and Forestry. Women forest rangers have also been established to create opportunity for women in combating IWT efforts. Further, the project and IP representative were also actively attended ASEAN working group on CITES.

The UNDP has effectively contributing to manage the combating illegal wildlife trade (IWT) in the national framework. UNDP has contributed in the development of National Strategy & Action Plan for combating IWT, and Economic Valuation Wildlife legalization process guidance to determine the economic value of animal traded. UNDP strengthened institutional capacity for implementation & enforcement CIWT by supporting the KAP Survey of communication strategy CIWT (with completion due date is 2021). In 2020, there were 530 law enforcement personnel have improved knowledge. UNDP has supported the institution with curriculum and training Modules for handling protected wildlife crime. To response COVID 19 situation, the UNDP also supports virtual training. As example, in collaboration with BP2SDM MoEF, an e-learning training will be prepared , comprises module on illegal wildlife crimes managerial, technical and attitudes.
To scale-up and improved enforcement strategy at key illegal wildlife trade, UNDP facilitated the Repatriation Wildlife from Philippines to Indonesia. Commitment to influence and support the gender inclusive working environment of the law Enforcement Unit has been showed this year by facilitating training of Inspiring Women to forest rangers at Bogani Nani Watabone National Park . Moreover, UNDP also supported the development of published SOP for animal handling, morphology analysis and DNA Forensic .

(1) Effective national framework for managing wildlife trade (review policies/laws, inter-agency taskforce operational); • Reviewed of Government Regulation No.8/1999 concerning utilization of wild plants & animals species, as well as other regulation related Law No. 5/1990 on Conservation of Biological Natural Resources and their Ecosystems • Developed an equal academic paper for formalization of the CIWT NASTRA. • Revisited and obtained approval of the draft report of the Economic Value Assessment of Protected Wildlife to Support Legal Process. • Drafted SOPs related to Preparation of Evidence for IWT Cases. • Drafted Preparation on Technical Guidelines for Implementing Administration Sanctions for the IWT Cases.
(2) Strengthened institutional capacity for implementation & enforcement at the national and international levels; • Organized National workshop on Strengthening Joint Strategies and Capacity Building on Cyber Patrol for all Gakkum units. • Installed of SIAP Gakkum - Software for Intelligence Center. • Species Validation of Mobile Application on Wildlife Identification. • Developed IWT Information Exchange Application with Financial Transaction Report and Analysis Center and Quarantine Agency. • Conducted Law Enforcement Training related to money laundry and illegal wildlife trade • Conducted Human Resources Capacity Building related to the Provision of Expert Judgement (identification of wildlife type and expert certification). • Conducted Animal Handling Training for Law Enforcement Officer related IWT. • Conducted Training for animal handling and management of human-wildlife conflict (HWC).
(3) Scaling-up improved enforcement strategy at key trade ports & connected ecosystem (increasing number cases prosecuted); • K9 Squad Development • Intelligence Training • Portmate Assessment • Strengthened Regional Task Force on CIWT • Strengthened Intelligence Networks on International IWT at National Borders (Indonesia-Malaysia) • Operations of Illegal Wildlife Trade • Study on Camera Trap Result Data and Pulbaket (Data Collection of Materials and Information) related to TSL Handling.
(4) Knowledge Management (at least 3 project lessons learned) • Developed Communication Strategy based on the national KAP Survey baseline. • Developed MLA (Mutual Legal Assistance) Good Practice on CIWT Joint Action (Indonesia and Netherlands) • Participated in the IWT Anti-trafficking Scout Jamboree/Persami Activities. • Monitoring and Evaluation of IWT E-Learning Training. • Strengthened Inspiring Women for forest rangers partners (PIMP) in the Prevention of IWT Hunting and Trafficking through alternative livelihoods. • Gender Mainstreaming Support (Internal Women Law Enforcement Forum) and LHK Gakkum External Facilitators.
